awd_titl_txt: Legal Forms of Firm Organization, Corporate Governance, and Business Expansion in the Middle East between 1887 and 1950
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite extensive studies on the adoption of legal forms of business organization and its relation to commercial expansion in the U.S. and Western Europe, the evolution of firm organization in the Middle East has received little attention. Due to the Middle East's important status in the past and present world economy, and its long and varied history of economic reforms, a greater understanding of Middle East economic history will yield insights about the region's historical development as well as determinants of business growth today. This project examines how legal institutions affect business formation and expansion, and more generally, what types of legal rules might be effective in fostering investment and commercial growth. Understanding the legal structures that promote business growth and establishment of a robust private sector reveals political and legal insights that promote successful enterprise. 

This project explores these questions by constructing a large, novel dataset of Turkish and Egyptian partnerships and corporations at the firm level between 1887 and 1950. The main sources of this dataset are business directories and commercial newspapers that published partnership contracts and corporation charters. The investigator will use this firm-level dataset to develop and test a theory of partnership formation and dissolution; examine the relationship between legal forms of firm organization, transplantation of European law, and business expansion; explore the links between corporate governance, industrialization and the political economy of these two countries; and investigate the disappearance of non-Muslim enterprises which had long dominated the Middle East's commercial life. The examination of corporations and their boards of directors, especially the formation of an interlocking directorate made up of securities underwriters and government members, will reveal the role of corporate governance and the state in industrialization, industrial organization, and firm performance.

por.por_cntn:
Recent discussions in economics view legal institutions as crucial determinants of development. The conventional view stresses the primacy of the corporation in Europe’s and the United States’ industrialization due to the form’s advantages in pooling and locking in capital. The corporation’s role is held especially significant for emerging economies, which imposed obstacles in mobilizing capital for new, large-scale enterprises beyond the modest personal wealth of individuals by restricting access to the corporate form. Specifically, the Islamic prohibition of the corporation was potentially an important factor that delayed industrialization in the Middle East. But few corporations existed in Western Europe during the onset of the industrial revolution; most industrial enterprises consisted of partnerships and single proprietorships.

Like other late industrializers, Ottoman/Turkish and Egyptian policymakers had to grapple with determining which types of business forms were better suited for organizing industrial capital. The political elite in these regions were keen on modernizing their legal systems using France and Germany as templates. This research project studies how legal rules on business organization evolved in Turkey and Egypt, how these forms affected firm dynamics and how they interacted with macroeconomic fluctuations during the tumultuous periods of late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries

To analyze the evolution of business organization in Turkey and Egypt, I constructed new datasets on all Egyptian multi-owner firms between 1911 and 1948, and all enterprises—single proprietorships and multi-owner firms—in Istanbul between 1926 and 1950, using hundreds of business notices and registrations records. I am also in the process of building another dataset on the population of Egyptian corporations established between 1887 and 1950 for which I digitized highly detailed information on governance rules, annual financial information, and monthly-frequency security prices using corporate charters deposited in the archives as well as statistical yearbooks. My next step is to take advantage of these new datasets to understand the determinants of firms’ governance structures and how these rules affected firm performance. These datasets will be valuable to wide scope of researchers in the social sciences. One of these datasets is published and made available to all researchers through the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR). Our studies as well others that rely on this new information will help develop a better insight of how industrialization policies of developing countries, legal modernization, and fluctuations in the business cycle affected firm organization, entry, exit, and growth, and how these dynamics affected aggregate adjustments. 

So far, the project has yielded several new findings. In one paper, I show that, if partners’ match quality is generally unknown, the relatively costless dissolution embedded in the partnership form allows members to experiment with different partners in a way that the corporate form cannot. Another paper reveals procyclical firm entry and countercyclical entrant quality across the business cycle by identifying the exogenous impact of aggregate fluctuations on firm dynamics. In doing so, this finding supports a view of costly market entry with ex ante heterogeneous firms as opposed to ex ante homogeneous potential entrants, providing new insights about how theory should model the macroeconomy. Two other papers reveal the central role non-Muslim minorities played in the business environment and economic development of Turkey and Egypt, and how discriminatory policies against non-Muslims created distortions on top of the horrible human cost. My next steps will be to finish the Egyptian corporation dataset to explore the determinants of corporate governance rules, investigate if common law provided stronger investor protection from insiders than civil law, and investigate how corporate governance interacted with firm outcomes. These findings will further contribute to our understanding of the economic implications of legal rules and how legal systems affected financial development.
